description: A substantial Romano-Celtic temple set within an extensive temenos, 1km east of the Roman town. The site shows some evidence of pre-invasion use in the early 1st century as a possible late Iron Age shrine and shows continued ritual activity up to the the late 4th or early 5th century.
bibliography: Alaimo, Katrina-Kay Sepulveda. “An Archaeology of Temple Assemblages and Social Practice in Early South-Eastern Roman Britain,” 2016.
Martyn, Blick, Brindle, and et al. “Great Chesterford Temple (Essex).” The Rural Settlement of Roman Britain: an online resource, 2015. https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449.
Medlycott. “The Roman Town of Great Chesterford.” East Anglian Archaeology 137 (2011).
Nash-Williams, A. K., and V. E. Nash-Williams. “Essex.” In Catalogue of the Roman Inscribed and Sculptured Stones Found at Caerleon, Vol. 23. Royal Commission on Historical Monuments, 1935.
Smith, Alex. “The Fate of Pagan Temples in South-East Britain.” In Ritual Landsacpes of South-East Britain, edited by David Rudling, 2008.
